newsitem.title: USA: U.S. economy robust - White House economist Yellen.
newsitem.headline: U.S. economy robust - White House economist Yellen.

text.p: New White House chief economist Janet Yellen Wednesday described the U.S. economy as robust, with growth strong and inflation low.
The government reported earlier that consumer prices rose by 0.1 percent in January and that the trade deficit widened by 29.6 percent in December.

In a statement, Yellen said the small increase in consumer prices last month was "well below market expectations. Over the past 12 months, the core inflation rate -- which excludes the volatile food and energy components -- was 2.5 percent, down from 3.0 percent during the previous year," she added.
Yellen, a former Federal Reserve Governor, played down the significance of the burgeoning U.S. trade deficit, blaming it on rising oil prices and oil imports.
According to the Commerce Department, the trade deficit increased by 8.2 percent last year, to $187.62 billion, its highest level since 1988.
"Relative to the size of the economy, the overall deficit (last year) was 1.5 percent, well below the deficits from 1983 to 1989," Yellen said.
